critique: This document pertains to an executive order by Franklin D. Roosevelt regarding the inspection of tax returns by special committees investigating receivership and bankruptcy proceedings. It amends a previous Treasury Decision to allow these committees access to tax returns. The document itself doesn't directly address ideological issues, immigration, or social inclusion. It primarily concerns government oversight and economic regulation through investigation of financial matters. The order expands executive power by granting access to tax returns, but it is also checked by the requirement of compliance with regulations prescribed by the Secretary of the Treasury and approved by the President. It also centralizes power at the federal level by enabling a Senate committee to investigate these matters. There is a balance between national security and civil liberties, as the investigation could uncover financial crimes, but it also involves access to private tax information.
